brief_summary.textblock:
Atrial fibrillation is the most frequent sustained arrhythmia. Catheter ablation is a
      procedure that is currently used for the treatment of symptomatic atrial fibrillation
      patients.

      We have organized a multi-centric national survey of catheter ablation of atrial
      fibrillation in order to have a feedback on the type of procedures being performed and the
      overall results (freedom of atrial fibrillation) over an average follow-up of 18 months.

clinical_study.brief_title: A French Multi-centric Atrial Fibrillation Catheter Ablation Survey
clinical_study.condition: Observation of Outcome After Catheter Ablation of Atrial Fibrillation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  all patients undergoing catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation or left atrial
             flutter

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  patients undergoing catheter ablation of other types of arrhythmia

study_pop.textblock: All patients undergoing catheter ablation in one of the registry centers

clinical_study.keyword: atrial fibrillation; catheter ablation; relapse; stroke; death
clinical_study.official_title: A French Multi-centric Atrial Fibrillation Catheter Ablation Survey

primary_outcome.description: Documentation of atrial fibrillation relapse (symptomatic or asymptomatic) after the first 3 months after the index procedure
primary_outcome.time_frame: starting 3 months after the procedure till an average of 18months follow-up

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Documented atrial fibrillation relapse (symptomatic or asymptomatic) in the first 3 months after the index procedure

collaborator.agency: University Hospital of Grenoble, Grenoble, France
Parly 2 Medical Surgical Center (CMC), Le Chesnay, France
University Hospital of Rouen, Rouen, France

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
